Page Title: Hakku Patra of Patam Rama Swamy [c 1800]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Patamvaru. Medium of original material: copper sheet square and rectangle. Description of material: The edge of upper part of copper plate is cut into cusp arch design. It contains the motifs of sun and moon to denote perpetuity, in the centre of the upper portion of the plate a Shivalinga, Nandi and Snake are engraved. Dimensions: length 31 cm, width 20 cm. The plate is donated by a villager named Mungonda Bhadraiah of Ajjaram Village. His relation P. Ramaswamy is unknown.                                                          View images from this file (2)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Page Title: Hakku Patra of Kadem Komuraiah [17th Century ]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Katipapalu. Medium of original material: copper sheet square and rectangle. Description of material: The edge of the upper part of the copper plate is cut into a cusp arch design with 11 curves. It contains the motifs of Shivalingam (God Shiva) and Nandis on both sides of the copper plate seen. On the front side are engraved letters, on the rear side of the plate there are sun and moon symbols with engraved letters. Dimensions: length 25 cm, width 20 cm, both sides of the plate are engraved with letters. No single inch of space is unwritten. There are 27 lines on the front side and 32 lines on the rear side of the plate. Thin letters and free hand style of writing is prominent. The details of donation and issuing of Hakku Patra institution is not known at present.                                                          View images from this file (2)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Page Title: Hakku Patra of Siripati Pedda Poshalu [18th Century ]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Katipapalu. Medium of original material: copper sheet square and rectangle. Description of material: The upper part of the copper plate is cut into eleven cusp arch design. It contains motifs of Shivalinga (symbol of Shiva) and Nandis and Snake on both sides, on the front side letters are engraved. On the rear side of the plate are the sun and the moon. Dimensions: length 25 cm, width 20 cm, both side of the plate are engraved with letters. No single inch of space is unwritten. There are 27 lines on the front side and 32 lines on the rear side of the plate. Thin letters and free hand style of writing is prominent. The details of donation and issuing institution of Hakku Patra are not known at present.                                                          View images from this file (2)

Page Title: Hakku Patra of Kadem Narasimha [17th Century ]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Katipapalu. Medium of original material: copper sheet square and rectangle. Description of material: The copper plate inscription certifies the right (Hakku) of ‘Kaatipaapalu’ community, a sub-ordinate caste of Maala/Madiga, to depend on and seek alms from Maala/Madiga community. Great part of this inscriptional text is all praise for Kaashi Viswanath/ an incarnation of Lord Siva. Dwelling much on greatness of Lord Siva, this inscription narrates that consequent to setting ablaze Manmatha, the God of love, a tear from the third eye of Lord Siva dropped in the burning pyre, so the “Katipaapadu’ was born, Lord Siva ordered him to execute the duty of watch dog of the Grave yard, and gave him a protection that nobody shall despise him, and every body shall love him as a son. This certificate further describes that the Kaatipaapadu be given a number of gifts viz., cow and calf, silver anklets, plate and pitcher, ear-rings and some coins too. He is entitled to take some belongings of the corpse – new cloth, golden bead put in the mouth etc., There is also a threat in this inscription that violators of the above norms will be cursed, those who abide by them will be blessed. The edge of the upper part of the copper plate has benn cut into 11 cusp arches. On front side there is a bird, village Goddess and Shivalingam and one Nandi is seen. On the Back side Moon and Sun and one Pillar before temple called Dwaja Stambam are seen.                                                          View images from this file (2)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Page Title: Hakku Patra of Siripati Narasimha [17th Century ]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Katipapalu. Medium of original material: copper plate. Description of material: The edge of the upper part of the copper plate is cut into seven cusp arches. On front side are Sun and Moon, two Nandis, Shiva and serpent. Dimensions: height 28 cm, width 18 cm. It is mentioned in the Hakku Patra that women those help Katipapalu by providing the need has to give freely two coppers. Even a mother is not great than this convention. Mala caste must give one rupee and washer-man has to provide cloth. Begara is also has right to receive help from other communities. The family member of deceased should give one Varaha (coin) or a calf so that deceased person will get much punyam (heaven). No one should scold him, he is like our child.                                                          View images from this file (2)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Adi Panasalu . Medium of original material: copper plate. Description of material: Front side of the copper plate is divided into 5 registers. All the five registers contain 15 divine and semi divine figures. There are figures of Trimurthy (Trinity of Hindu pantheon), Vinayaka (Elephant God), Kalika (Dark Goddesses), Priest, Hanuman, Manubrahma and her daughter, Twastha Brahma, Shilpi Brahma, Viswa Brahma, Panasa Kumara and Panasa tree, Vahana Kapari, Mirror of Kalika, and the last register has Iravatam (elephant) and Aswa (Horse). Back side of the copper plate inscription refers to Ibrahim Quli Qutub-Shah (Malkibharam). He was one of the rulers from Golkonda dynasty in 1580 AD. Dimensions: height 24 cm, width 12 cm.                                                          View images from this file (2)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Page Title: Paper Hakku Patra of Salla Yadagiri [1841]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Budiga Jangalu. Medium of original material: paper document. Description of material: Front side of this paper document starts with Kasi Viswanatharpanamasthu sentence and given to Kashi Nilakanta Swamy and signed by four chefs with two official seals in Urdu languages. Dimensions: length 32 cm, width 21 cm. This paper document was written in the month of June, 1841 AD. On the request of disciple Ramachandra, on behalf of Kashi Neelakanta Swamiji, a new document was written in place of the old one as it was in deteriorated condition. The document says “As it was assigned, and your disciple Ramachandra brought the message in written obliging the content, the inhabitants of Adlur ………… every year take care to pay them off properly. A similar ordinance is also been written and been brought to Varushachala with blessings.” The document is signed by Akkinepalli Venkata Narsaiah Deshpande and Anantha Rao Deshpande of Adluru village, Nalgonda Dist.                                                          View images from this file (1)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Page Title: Paper Hakku Patra of Salla Shanbulingam [1845]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Budiga Jangalu. Medium of original material: paper document. Description of material: This one page document is divided into two parts. The three signatures are accommodated in the middle of fourteen village names as mentioned on the left side. Hakku and other details were given on the right side portion. Dimensions: height 34 cm, width 21 cm. This paper document is written in the year shubha Krut, on thirteenth day of the month Ashweeyuja to Kaashi Neela Kantham Swamiji by Boddupalli Gundanna Narsaiah. Sheshanna Deshpande, resident of Vodichetu Sarkar, Nallagonda. It is referred to the year 1253, place Saluku Taluka, Vennavaram Village. As the document condition is in deteriorated stage. Hence this document was rewritten and submitted to different mutts. Every year in each village he should get donations and should perform all the rituals.                                                          View images from this file (1)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Page Title: Paper Hakku Patra of Salla Veeraiah [1841]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Budiga Jangalu. Medium of original material: paper document. Description of material: This paper document is a deed of transfer of rights executed by Kodanda Ramaiah Venkatarangarao Deshmukh of Khmammam met in the year 1841 AD. The contents of the document reveal that Tallada and other villages of Saluma Taluq were given to Kashi Neelakanta Swamiji Mutt as religious donation. To that effect a new document was being written as the old one got deteriorated. Seeking blessings from swamiji and the obliging the ordinance brought by swamiji’s disciple Mahendurdu, the Deshmuk reiterates that contributions and donations from the villages would go to the Mutt regularly. The document has two signatures in Telugu and one see in Urdu. Dimensions: height 35 cm, width 15 cm.                                                          View images from this file (1)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Page Title: Paper Hakku Patra of Salla Veeraiah [1841]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Budiga Jangalu. Medium of original material: One paper document. Description of material: This paper document is a deed of transfer of rights executed by Vutyalanthaiah Venkatramaiah Deshmukh in the year 1841 AD. The contents of the document reveal that 14 villages were given to Kashi Neelakanta swamiji Mutt as a religious donation. To that effect a new document was written as the old one got deteriorated. Seeking blessings from the Mutt, Obliging the ordinance brought by the Swamiji’s disciple Ramulaiah, the Deshmukh reiterates that donations would go to the Mutt regularly. Names of donated villages are listed in the document. It has two seals in Urdu, two signatures in Telugu language. Dimensions: height 35 cm, width 20 cm.                                                          View images from this file (1)

Page Title: Hakku Patra of Miriyala Somaiah [17th Century ]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Madiga Jangalu . Medium of original material: copper sheet square and rectangle. Page Title: Hakku Patra of Tanda Amaraiah [01 Feb 1942]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Terachiralavaru. Medium of original material: Old Paper. Description of material: This paper document dated 1 February 1942 at Suryapet, Nalgonda District is a resolution of heads of Golla Community. The Chinna Rajalingam, Village Jayyaram, Taluq Manukota was given this acceptance document by the Jury of the heads. A dispute arises when pala cherlaiah has not given share in Lingamanthula Jatara. Hence giving Honorarium /donations was stopped. Now both sides agreed to accept and honor the old terms and conditions to get equal share. Page Title: Hakku Patra of Chenchu Mandala Narasimha [18th Century ]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Chenchuvaru. Medium of original material: Copper sheets, one square and another rectangular. Description of material: The plate has seven cusp arch form. The plate is in rectangular shape. The plate is small in size. At the front of the plate one vaishnava religious symbol is painted. This copper plate was issued during a period of Krishan Prashad, who was a Prime Minister of VII Nizam (1870 – 1930 approximately). The Patti (area of the 40 villages) mentioned in the inscription which include Suryapet, Miriyalaguda, Nalgonda, Devarakonda, Khammam. The inscription orders that every house in this region should give Manaid (3 Kg.) grains and Rs. 50/-. Every Dalit family should give One Tavva (1¼ Kg.) of grain and Rs. 10/- to the performer community. All these villagers have to respect this order by not giving to the communities whose names are not mentioned in this copper plate.                                                          View images from this file (2)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Page Title: Hakku Patra of Mandala Ramulu [18th Century ]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Chenchuvaru. Medium of original material: copper plate on both sides. Description of material: The upper part of this copper plate is cut into seven cusp arch pattern. The top of the plate is painted with white and red colours. This pattern of colour symbolically represent the vaishnava religion. The content of the copper plate described the origin of the Chenchu tribe. At the time of genesis of the world, this Shasanam (inscription) appeared. According to this inscription the villages of Juluru, Papkallu, Madira Taluq, Siri Puram, Balakonda, Kothagudem, Illendu and other Territories were given to Gunugujjulu Ramadiya son of Muthaylu. Kapu (cultivator’s community) and Karanam (revenue record keeper) have to support and recognized the matter described in the copper inscription.                                                          View images from this file (2)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Mandahetchu. Medium of original material: copper plate. Description of material: The copper plate reveals the history of Mandahetchu community and its origin and the context of the origin. The period mentioned in the copper plate inscription is 1543 AD. The inscription describes about twenty five places. Many of them are historical. The wars fought by Katamaraju, Ayathamaraju and Kancharla are all historically significant. But the period of this kings is not mentioned clearly by the historians. The patron caste of Mandahetchu is Yadava/Golla (Shepherd) which lives in the plains. They go in search of pastoral fields. Thus they go to Nellore, which is nearly 500 km from Nalgonda. After his marriage with Ganga, Katamaraju ordered Manda Boyadu (Jaggayya) to feed ‘Balimudha’ (a ritual feed) to all the cattle. So he did feed. Then onwards the Boyadu was called ‘Mandahetchu’ and was conferred the privilege of being looked after by twelve sects of Yadava community. The copper plate inscription categorically mentioned that the owner of 10 cows should give one cow, the owner of 9 goats should give one lamb, the working persons should give one month income to the Mandahetchu. It also mentions that in the name of those who died, cows, gold rings, silver anklets etc., must be given to him. He shall enjoy this privilege forever. It seems long back this copper plate is given to one family. After some time, out of one copper plate, shares were given to two families with small modifications in the text. The two versions are available in one village with Kinnera Pedabhushaiah and Kadem Inakomulu.                                                          View images from this file (2)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Page Title: Hakku Patra of Kinnera Peda Bhushaiah [1543]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Mandahetchu. Medium of original material: copper plate square and rectangle. Description of material: The edge of the upper part of the copper plate is cut into 11 cusp arches. At the top, a Siva Lingam is flanked by two Nandies on either side. At the top of back side is a lamp stand, flanked by the Moon and the Sun. The copper plate reveals the history of Mandahetchu community and its origin and the context of the origin.The period mentioned in the copper plate inscription is 1543 AD. The inscription describes about twenty five places. Many of them are historical. The wars fought by Katamaraju, Ayathamaraju and Kancharla are all historically significant. But the period of these kings is not mentioned clearly by the historians. The copper plate inscription categorically mentioned that the owner of 10 cows should give one cow, the owner of 9 goats should give one lamb, the working persons should give one month income to the Mandahetchu. It also mentions that in the name of those who died, cows, gold rings, silver anklets etc., must be given to him. He shall enjoy this privilege forever. It seems that a long time ago this copper plate was given to one family. After some time, out of one copper plate, shares were given to two families with small modifications in the text. The two versions are available in one village with Kinnera Pedabhushaiah and Kadem Inakomulu.                                                          View images from this file (2)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Gotralavaru. Medium of original material: copper plate. Description of material: ‘Gothram’ indicates the details of the sects and surnames within the same caste or community. Further details of the Gothram could be observed. People sharing the same, identical Gothram are restricted to marry. It is a taboo. The ancestral history of the sects and details of their Gothram play vital role in caste hierarchy. Hence the duty of memorizing and maintaining these Gotharams are entrusted to this caste. They remember all names of Gothram of the relevant sects/castes and let other people also know their Gothram. It is their duty to go to the families in the villages which are assigned to them.                                                          View images from this file (2)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Beerannalavaru. Medium of original material: paper document. Description of material: This paper document was written in 1890 (approximately) Janapaiah Gurumurthulu of Siddeswaralaya Matham of Kolanupaka Taluq. Obviously, it is a deed of rights given to Beerannalu, a sub-caste of kuruma. (One Adireddy was the executor of this deed?). 12 Taluqas (paraganas) were allotted to Diddige family to carry on their religious/ritual activities on the eve of Mallanna Panduga/ Beerappa festivals and enjoy the remuneration he received. It is also mentioned in the copied document that the Beerannalu community went from one place to another an account of the famine. It is described that the ‘Kambali’ (blanket) woven by Beerannalu occupies an important place in the lives of common men as well as elites. The deed also stipulates some rules for Beerannalu, like barring liquor & meat consumption in general. This document was executed by Janapaiah, Guru of Kolanupaka village before 21 persons as witnesses.                                                          View images from this file (3)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Beerannalavaru. Medium of original material: copper plate. Dimensions: height 55 cm, width 20 cm. On the front side of the plate there are two round faced women, who resemble Moon and Sun. A small Shiva Linga on pranamattam and in the middle of plate is a sketch of a horse. Upper part of plate, on front side, is cut into five cusp arches. The text of the plate extols the virtue of the donor and back side of the plate has the detail of the name of the donor and his caste. The rights were offered to Beerappa for all the fairs and festivals which were celebrated in and around the village in that region. It is also mentioned in the plate that it is the responsibility of the caste people to pay to each churning stick family, one goat and woolen blanket weaver family should pay him eight paisa.                                                          View images from this file (2)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Page Title: Hakku Patra of Soma Sambaiah [19th Century ]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Korraju. Medium of original material: copper plate. Description of material: Korrajulu own a painted scroll and a copper plate as deeds. Dimensions: height 15 cm, width 12 cm. On the front side of the copper plate are carved Nandi, Sun, Moon, Shiva Lingam, a fish and a lotus flower. It is observed by the Surveyor that if Korraju sings for others, than their assigned villages, singers do not use the painted scroll. They use only a stringed musical instrument. They do not even sing the ‘Padmanayaka Katha’ on these occasions. At the end of the copper plate, the list of the villages is given, which are assigned to them in Grant. The copper plate gives the details of the rights of the Korraju and further describes that each hearth (Kitchen) has to pay five hundred rupees. Otherwise the particular person would be outcasted from the community. The person, who owns copper plate, visit each assigned villages in two or three years. No other Korraju visit except the owner of copper plate. Korraju is the devotee of padmanayakulu. Hence, he is entitled to sing the ‘Pandava Katha’.                                                          View images from this file (2)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Page Title: Hakku Patra of Akula Sammaiah [10 May 1971]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Enuti. Medium of original material: paper document. Description of material: This paper document was written recently on 10 Mar 1971. The executors of this deed of right are Akula Venkataiah and Akula Somaiah they have endorsed the deed with their thumb impressions. This deed reveals that eight villages were sold (transfer of the right for taking honorarium) to Balagani Narasaiah, belonging to the same cast Enuti. The deed has signatures of four witnesses.                                                          View images from this file (1)

Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Ogguvaru. Medium of original material: copper plate. Description of material: The copper plate inscription mentions the names of villages assigned to Ogguvaru. Ogguvaru, a sub-caste of Golla / Yadava narrate the epics of Mallanna and Ellamma by beating a drum (Dolu) and playing taala. It is their profession. They have the right to tour all assigned villages with the team. Each team consisting of ten to twenty performers. On the eve of festivals they also perform Pooja (worship).                                                          View images from this file (2)

Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Medara Matam Guruvulu. Medium of original material: Paper scroll. Dimensions: height 495 cm, width 30.5 cm. This is a typical Hakku Patra available in Medara Mutt (basket weavers). The name of donors and head of the villagers are given in the scroll. It reveals the Shiva Bhakthi as their faith. Their profession in rural areas as well in Tribal India is making of baskets and broomsticks. The duties of Medara Gurus are also mentioned in this scroll. In the beginning of the paper scroll there is a colorful painting depicting a Shiva Linga, which is surrounded by a serpent, two devotees are standing by the linga, and two nandis sitting in the lower portion. In the next portion five men working with bamboo making baskets etc. with their tools. The paper scroll also contains a big list of signatures.                                                          View images from this file (16)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.

Page Title: Hakku Patra of M. Veera Manemma [1732]
Description: Contributor / Caste / Performance: Medara Matam Guruvulu. Medium of original material: Paper scroll. Description of material: This paper scroll is prepared to record the list of disciples who belong to different villages. Names and address of disciples were recorded. Dimensions: width 21.2 cm, length 709 cm. It contains no illustrations. This paper scroll document written approximately in 1732 AD. The contents of the document reveals that certain Guru called Medara Kethama Shetti was authorized to perform Pooja with all rituals in Medara Mattam of Kolanupaka. Those who violate this system would be penalized according to the stipulations laid down in the documents. 90% of the scroll is filled with the names of the persons who agreed for this authorization, and the names of the villages these persons belong.                                                          View images from this file (15)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only.
